articles.headline: Think QAnon Is on the Fringe? So Was the Tea Party
articles.snippet: Followers of the pro-Trump conspiracy movement are winning elections and worrying moderate Republicans. Sound familiar?
articles.abstract: Followers of the pro-Trump conspiracy movement are winning elections and worrying moderate Republicans. Sound familiar?
articles.lead_paragraph: Democrats dismissed it as a fringe group of conspiracy-minded zealots. Moderate Republicans fretted over its potential to hurt their party’s image, while more conservative lawmakers carefully sought to harness its grass-roots energy. Sympathetic media outlets covered its rallies, portraying it as an emerging strain of populist politics — a protest movement born of frustration with a corrupt, unaccountable elite.

articles.headline: Trump’s Labor Chief Accused of Intervening in Oracle Pay Bias Case
articles.snippet: A Labor Department lawyer asserts that she faced reprisal after saying Secretary Eugene Scalia was set to settle a suit for a sum she found too low.
articles.abstract: A Labor Department lawyer asserts that she faced reprisal after saying Secretary Eugene Scalia was set to settle a suit for a sum she found too low.
articles.lead_paragraph: A senior Labor Department lawyer contends she faces removal from her job after objecting to Labor Secretary Eugene Scalia’s intervention in a pay discrimination case against Oracle, a tech giant with close White House connections.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber, David McCabe and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Fortnite Creator Sues Apple and Google After Ban From App Stores
articles.snippet: Epic Games, the maker of the popular game, provoked the tech giants by violating their policies, then released a social media campaign and lawsuits to confront them.
articles.abstract: Epic Games, the maker of the popular game, provoked the tech giants by violating their policies, then released a social media campaign and lawsuits to confront them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple’s and Google’s spats with app developers over their cut of revenues exploded into a high-stakes clash on Thursday when the tech giants kicked the wildly popular game Fortnite out of their app stores and the game’s maker hit back with lawsuits.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas, Kellen Browning and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Accuses Yale of Discrimination in Application Process
articles.snippet: The Trump administration said the university discriminated against Asian-American and white applicants. Yale defended its practices and vowed to maintain them.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration said the university discriminated against Asian-American and white applicants. Yale defended its practices and vowed to maintain them.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department on Thursday accused Yale University of violating federal civil rights law by discriminating against Asian-American and white applicants, an escalation of the Trump administration’s moves against race-based admissions policies at elite universities.

articles.headline: $400 Unemployment Supplement Is Really $300, and Won’t Arrive Soon
articles.snippet: New state claims fell below one million for the first week since March. But jobless ranks remain vast, and a White House relief plan faces hurdles.
articles.abstract: New state claims fell below one million for the first week since March. But jobless ranks remain vast, and a White House relief plan faces hurdles.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal aid to unemployed workers that President Trump announced last weekend looks likely to be smaller than initially suggested — and it remains unclear when the money will start flowing, how long it will last or how many workers will benefit.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: How Biden Chose Harris: A Search That Forged New Stars, Friends and Rivalries
articles.snippet: Joe Biden winnowed a large list of candidates to four finalists before settling on Kamala Harris, in a process shaped by questions of loyalty. He is eyeing other contenders for top administration jobs.
articles.abstract: Joe Biden winnowed a large list of candidates to four finalists before settling on Kamala Harris, in a process shaped by questions of loyalty. He is eyeing other contenders for top administration jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Read our profile of Kamala Harris, the first woman elected U.S. vice president.]
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns, Jonathan Martin and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: Trump Makes Clear His Opposition to More Money to Support Mail Voting
articles.snippet: The president’s remarks fueled alarm among Democrats that he is seeking to undercut the election and sow confusion about the outcome.
articles.abstract: The president’s remarks fueled alarm among Democrats that he is seeking to undercut the election and sow confusion about the outcome.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump stirred new questions on Thursday about whether he would seek to hold up new money to the Postal Service to impede mail-in voting this fall in the middle of the pandemic.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane and Hailey Fuchs

articles.headline: Netanyahu Drops Troubled Annexation Plan for Diplomatic Gain
articles.snippet: In an abrupt reversal, Israel’s prime minister “suspended” a promise to annex part of the West Bank in exchange for a historic opening with the U.A.E.
articles.abstract: In an abrupt reversal, Israel’s prime minister “suspended” a promise to annex part of the West Bank in exchange for a historic opening with the U.A.E.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — For the past 16 months, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel had doggedly pursued a right-wing dream that he saw as securing his legacy: annexing West Bank territory that the Palestinians counted on for a future state, potentially dealing a death blow to a two-state solution.

articles.headline: State and Local Budget Pain Looms Over Economy’s Future
articles.snippet: Providing more aid to struggling governments has become one of the biggest issues tangling up the debate over another pandemic rescue package.
articles.abstract: Providing more aid to struggling governments has become one of the biggest issues tangling up the debate over another pandemic rescue package.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The U.S. economy struggled to shake off the last recession, with historically slow growth and a labor market that took more than six years to recover its earlier employment levels. A big part of the reason: state and local governments, which cut spending and fired workers amid widespread budget shortfalls.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek, Alan Rappeport and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: A Third of TikTok’s U.S. Users May Be 14 or Under, Raising Safety Questions
articles.snippet: Three current and former employees expressed concerns about the Chinese-owned app’s safeguards for preteen children.
articles.abstract: Three current and former employees expressed concerns about the Chinese-owned app’s safeguards for preteen children.
articles.lead_paragraph: If Microsoft or another company buys TikTok before President Trump bans the Chinese-owned video app on national security grounds, it will acquire a giant community of devoted fans and a lucrative platform for selling ads.
articles.byline: By Raymond Zhong and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: Families Priced Out of ‘Learning Pods’ Seek Alternatives
articles.snippet: Should public school systems provide teachers for small-group instruction?
articles.abstract: Should public school systems provide teachers for small-group instruction?
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Shy Rodriguez heard about one of the hottest trends in education during the pandemic — “learning pods,” where parents hire teachers for small-group, in-home instruction — she knew immediately it was something she could never afford for her sons.

articles.headline: For Palestinians, Israel-U.A.E. Deal Swaps One Nightmare for Another
articles.snippet: With annexation of the West Bank off the table and Arab diplomacy turned inside out, the Palestinian struggle, once focused against Israel, now is to remain relevant.
articles.abstract: With annexation of the West Bank off the table and Arab diplomacy turned inside out, the Palestinian struggle, once focused against Israel, now is to remain relevant.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — When the unmarked United Arab Emirates plane touched down on the tarmac in Tel Aviv one night in May carrying 16 tons of unsolicited medical aid for the Palestinians, it was rejected by the Palestinian leadership, which said that nobody had coordinated with them about the shipment.
articles.byline: By Isabel Kershner and Adam Rasgon

articles.headline: Taking Hard Line, Greece Turns Back Migrants by Abandoning Them at Sea
articles.snippet: Many Greeks have grown frustrated as tens of thousands of asylum seekers languished on Greek islands. Now, evidence shows, a new conservative government has a new method of keeping them out.
articles.abstract: Many Greeks have grown frustrated as tens of thousands of asylum seekers languished on Greek islands. Now, evidence shows, a new conservative government has a new method of keeping them out.
articles.lead_paragraph: RHODES, Greece — The Greek government has secretly expelled more than 1,000 refugees from Europe’s borders in recent months, sailing many of them to the edge of Greek territorial waters and then abandoning them in inflatable and sometimes overburdened life rafts.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Karam Shoumali
